questions.question: What is the purpose of life?

verses.relevanceNote: This verse directly states the purpose: to worship and know Allah. Worship here means complete submission and recognition of the Creator.
Life is a test - we are placed here to demonstrate righteous action. The purpose includes moral growth and spiritual development.
Humanity's role as khalifah (vicegerent) on earth - to establish justice and goodness.
Allah's mercy is infinite - despair not! This verse emphasizes that no sin is too great for Allah's forgiveness if one sincerely repents.
Exception: shirk (associating partners with Allah) if one dies in that state. But even shirk can be forgiven if one repents before death.
Allah is self-sufficient and needs nothing from creation. Worship benefits us, not Allah - it purifies our souls and brings us closer to Him.
Humanity needs Allah, but Allah needs nothing. This verse emphasizes divine transcendence and human dependence.

questions.question: How can I strengthen my faith?

verses.relevanceNote: Faith increases through remembrance of Allah, reciting the Quran, and reflecting on His signs. The Quran itself strengthens belief.
Contemplating creation - the heavens and earth - increases faith and understanding of divine power.
Allah is near and responds to those who call upon Him. He hears every prayer and knows every need, even before we ask.
Allah commands us to call upon Him and promises to respond. He considers prayer an act of worship and never ignores it.

questions.question: How do I get closer to God?

verses.relevanceNote: Remember Allah constantly, and He will remember you. Divine proximity comes through dhikr (remembrance) and gratitude.
Allah is closer to you than your jugular vein. Closeness is achieved by recognizing His constant presence in your life.
True worship means being sincere to Allah alone, establishing prayer, and giving charity. It combines devotion with righteous action.
Prayer without compassion for others is incomplete. True worship integrates ritual with ethics and social responsibility.
Allah created humanity and jinn to know and worship Him. Our existence has divine purpose beyond material pursuits.
We are created as Allah's vicegerents on earth - to establish justice, goodness, and divine order in creation.

questions.question: Why do bad things happen to good people?

verses.relevanceNote: Trials test faith and purify souls. Hardship is not punishment but a means of spiritual growth and elevation.
Testing is how Allah distinguishes truth from falsehood in hearts. Faith must be proven through trials, not mere words.
Through hardship, Allah identifies true believers who remain steadfast. Ease without trial does not reveal character.

questions.question: Why is there suffering in the world?

verses.relevanceNote: Life is a test to see who acts best. Suffering exists as part of this test, revealing our choices between good and evil.
The world is made beautiful yet temporary to test us. Suffering reminds us not to become attached to this fleeting life.

questions.question: Where is God when I'm hurting?

verses.relevanceNote: Allah is near, especially to those who call upon Him in distress. He hears and knows our pain intimately.
With every hardship comes ease. Allah promises relief and never abandons those who suffer - ease follows difficulty.
Every atom's weight of good or evil will be seen and judged. Perfect justice awaits on the Day of Judgment - nothing escapes Allah's knowledge.
Allah does not wrong anyone, not even by an atom's weight. Injustice in this world will be rectified in the Hereafter.
Allah commands justice and good conduct. While this world has trials, ultimate fairness will be established in the Hereafter.
On Judgment Day, scales of justice will be set up with perfect precision. No soul will be wronged in the slightest.
No soul is burdened beyond its capacity. Children who suffer will be compensated justly by Allah's infinite mercy and wisdom.
All creation glorifies Allah, even if we don't understand the wisdom. Children's suffering has meaning in Allah's perfect plan.
Worship Allah and be good to parents, relatives, orphans, the needy, neighbors, travelers, and all people. Kindness is universal.
All humanity comes from one source. The most honored in Allah's sight are those with most taqwa (consciousness of Allah), not race or status.

questions.question: What makes something right or wrong?

verses.relevanceNote: Allah has inspired every soul with understanding of right (taqwa) and wrong (fujur). Conscience is divinely implanted.
Allah commands justice, good conduct, and generosity. He forbids immorality, wrongdoing, and oppression. These are moral absolutes.

questions.question: How do I control my anger?

verses.relevanceNote: The righteous are those who restrain anger and pardon others. Allah loves those who show such self-control and forgiveness.
Practice forgiveness, command what is right, and turn away from the ignorant. Respond to anger with grace and wisdom.
True righteousness includes giving wealth to family, orphans, the needy, travelers, and for freeing slaves - out of love for Allah, not for show.
Charity done for show or followed by reminders of generosity is worthless. Give sincerely, in secret, without seeking recognition.

questions.question: Should I forgive those who hurt me?

verses.relevanceNote: Pardon and overlook offenses. Don't you love that Allah should forgive you? As you show mercy to others, Allah shows mercy to you.
While justice is allowed, forgiving is better. Allah loves those who pardon others - forgiveness is a higher virtue than retribution.
The servants of the Most Merciful walk on earth humbly, and when the ignorant address them, they say 'Peace.' Gentleness defines character.
Do not turn your face away from people arrogantly, nor walk proudly on earth. Allah does not love the self-conceited boaster.
Do not backbite - would you like to eat the flesh of your dead brother? Backbiting is compared to this repulsive act. Guard your tongue.
Those who spread slander about believers will face painful punishment. Speaking ill of others is a grave sin.
After death comes barzakh - an intermediate realm until resurrection. Then all will be raised for the Day of Judgment.
Humans were not created to be left purposeless. Death is not the end - resurrection and accountability await everyone.

questions.question: Is there really a Day of Judgment?

verses.relevanceNote: The Day of Judgment is real - a day when no soul can help another, and all authority belongs to Allah alone. Perfect justice will prevail.
Scales of justice will be set up on Judgment Day. Not even an atom's weight of good or evil will be overlooked.
Paradise has rivers of water, milk, wine (that doesn't intoxicate), and honey. Gardens of eternal bliss await the righteous.
No soul knows the delights of Paradise that await them - rewards beyond imagination as recompense for righteous deeds.
Those who die associating partners with Allah (shirk) without repenting will be denied Paradise. However, Allah forgives all other sins if He wills.
Those who committed evil will see it judged. Hell is for persistent wrongdoers who rejected truth and oppressed others.
Believers will be reunited with their faithful family members in Paradise. Allah will join them together out of His mercy.
Gardens of eternity where righteous ones enter along with their righteous ancestors, spouses, and descendants. A complete family reunion.
Allah keeps believers firm in the grave and in the Hereafter through their faith. They will answer questions from angels with certainty.
Those who turn away from Allah's remembrance will face a constrained life in the grave and be raised blind on Judgment Day.

questions.question: How should I treat my parents?

verses.relevanceNote: Worship Allah alone and be kind to parents. If they reach old age, do not say 'uff' to them but speak honorably and gently.
Be grateful to Allah and your parents. Even if they urge you toward shirk, refuse gently but still treat them kindly in this world.

questions.question: What are the rights of spouses?

verses.relevanceNote: Allah created spouses as a source of tranquility, love, and mercy. Marriage is a sign of divine wisdom and compassion.
Spouses have rights over each other in fairness. Men and women are garments for each other - protection, comfort, and adornment.

questions.question: How do I raise righteous children?

verses.relevanceNote: Protect yourselves and your families from Hell by teaching them faith, prayer, and righteousness. Parents are responsible for their children's guidance.
Teach children to establish prayer, command good, forbid evil, and be patient with difficulties. Model these virtues yourself.
Keep company with those who remember Allah morning and evening. Don't follow those whose hearts are heedless and who pursue worldly desires.
On Judgment Day, wrongdoers will regret taking certain people as friends who led them astray. Choose companions who strengthen your faith.

questions.question: How do I deal with difficult relatives?

verses.relevanceNote: Maintain ties of kinship - Allah watches over family relationships. Honor relatives even when they make it difficult.
Those who break family ties that Allah commanded to be maintained earn His curse. Patience with difficult relatives brings divine reward.
Allah placed love and mercy between spouses. A blessed marriage is built on mutual tranquility, affection, and compassion.
Righteous spouses pray to be the comfort of each other's eyes and leaders in piety. Shared faith strengthens marital bonds.

questions.question: What does Islam say about other faiths?

verses.relevanceNote: Believers, Jews, Christians, and Sabians - whoever believes in Allah and the Last Day and does good will be rewarded. Faith and righteous deeds matter most.
Argue with People of the Book only in the best manner, acknowledging shared belief in one God. Approach interfaith dialogue with respect.
Among the People of the Book are upright communities who recite Allah's verses throughout the night and prostrate. Not all are the same.
You will find Christians nearest in affection to Muslims because among them are priests and monks who are humble and devout.

questions.question: Can people of other faiths be good?

verses.relevanceNote: Those who believe in Allah, the Last Day, and do righteous deeds will have their reward with Allah. Goodness transcends religious labels.
Believers, Jews, Sabians, and Christians who believe in Allah and the Last Day and do good have nothing to fear. Sincerity matters.
Allah could have made humanity one nation but made you different to test you. Compete in goodness - in the end, Allah will clarify your differences.
Allah made humanity into nations and tribes so you may know one another. Diversity is by divine design, meant to foster understanding.
Allah does not forbid you from being kind and just to those who haven't fought you over religion. Allah loves those who are just.
All humanity comes from one source. Honor is based on righteousness, not ethnicity or religion. Treat all people with dignity.

questions.question: Can I lie to save someone?

verses.relevanceNote: Those forced to disbelieve while their hearts remain firm in faith are excused. Under extreme duress, protecting life takes precedence.
Allah will not take you to task for unintentional oaths. Intentions matter - protecting innocent life is a higher principle than strict truthfulness.
When believers commit sin, they remember Allah and seek forgiveness immediately. They don't persist in wrongdoing knowingly.
Never despair of Allah's mercy. He forgives all sins for those who sincerely repent. Turn to Him with genuine remorse and resolve.
